items.title: Leveraging tax credits and incentives for sustainability projects

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Randa Barsoum, Tax Partner at PwC US, highlights that energy tax incentives are only part of the sustainability tax picture and that less obvious credits and incentives can also support sustainability efforts. She points to state and local abatements, location-based incentives, and R&D tax credits tied to innovation (for example, reimagining packaging or processes) and emphasizes that viewing sustainability investments through a broader tax lens can unlock meaningful tax value.
bullets: Energy incentives are commonly top of mind but not the whole story.
State and local abatements can support sustainability projects.
Location-based incentives are another underused lever.
R&D tax credits may apply to innovation efforts (e.g., reimagining packaging or processes).
A broader tax perspective on sustainability investments can yield meaningful tax value.
takeaways: Include state and local abatements and location-based incentives in site-selection and sustainability planning for grid/data center projects.
Evaluate R&D tax credit eligibility for innovation in processes, designs, or operational improvements tied to sustainability efforts.
Expand tax-planning beyond traditional energy incentives to capture additional financial value from sustainability investments.

items.title: Bringing In $251K A Year With 3 Jobs In The Bay Area

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Naseema McElroy, 44, is a labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, California who also runs a personal finance brand and brings in $251K a year across three jobs. She amassed nearly $1 million in debt by 2015, started Financially Intentional to document her debt-payoff journey, and was debt-free by 2017.
bullets: Naseema McElroy, 44, is an L&D nurse and founder of Financially Intentional.
Title states she earns $251K/year working three jobs in the Bay Area.
Had nearly $1M in debt in 2015 and documented her repayment journey through her business.
She became debt-free by 2017.
This profile is part of CNBC Make It's Millennial Money series.
takeaways: The video is a personal finance profile and does not provide operational or technical information relevant to grid or data center capacity planning.
No details on energy use, remote work impact, or local infrastructure are provided, so it does not imply changes for grid or data center operations.
As a single anecdotal profile, it is insufficient as a dataset for strategic planning or trend analysis in the grid/data center domain.
No direct action or decision-making guidance for grid or data center managers can be drawn from this description alone.

items.title: TTEC accelerates AI deployment and revenue streams with Google Cloud Consulting

ai.summary: Based on the available description, TTEC partnered with Google Cloud Consulting to rapidly prototype and deploy AI solutions that unlocked entirely new revenue streams. Sreeni Alakappan notes TTEC used GenAI and Google Cloud's robust infrastructure to streamline operations, boost developer productivity, and compress their digital transformation timeline.
bullets: TTEC collaborated with Google Cloud Consulting to accelerate AI prototyping and deployment.
GenAI and Google Cloud infrastructure were used to streamline operations and improve developer productivity.
The partnership enabled TTEC to unlock new revenue streams.
Google Cloud Consulting helped compress TTECâ€™s digital transformation timeline.
The engagement expanded TTECâ€™s business ambitions for AI-driven solutions.
takeaways: Investing in cloud-native AI (GenAI) can create new revenue opportunities for services-driven businesses.
Robust cloud infrastructure supports faster AI deployment and operational improvements.
Engaging cloud consulting partners can shorten transformation timelines and de-risk prototyping.
Improved developer productivity via AI tooling can accelerate feature delivery and operational efficiency.
